EXTERNAL EVIDENCE FOR THE AUTHENTICITY OF THE EPISTLE

lDirect evidence: Eusebius in his account of the Canonical books classes it ¹ amongst the Antileqomena, but elsewhere cites it as genuine, p. xlvii. It is omitted 111 the Muratorian fragment and in the Canon Mommsenianus 3 but included in the Peshitto and in the Catalogues of Origen, Cyril os Jerusalem, Gregory of Nazianzus, Athanasius, Amphilochius of Iconium, Epiphanius, Jerome and Augustine, and was finally accepted by the third Council of Carthage, p. xlviii. Indirect evidence .- was known to Clement of Rome, to the author of the Didache, of the Epistle os Barnabas, and of the Testaments of the Patriarchs, to Ignatius and to Polycarp, p. 1. Hermas is full of allusions to it, p. lvii. It is referred to by Justin Martyr, Athenagoras, Irenaeus, Theophilus, Clement of Alexandria, and by the writers of the Ep. ad Diognetum, and the Acta Johannis, p. lxi. Origen first cites it by name as Scripture and as the work of St. J ames, p. lxiii. Allusions are also found to it in Tertullian, Dionysius of Alexandria, Gregory Thaumaturgus, the Clementine Homilies, Consti- tutiones Apostolicae, Lactantius, Athanasius, Chrysostoin and Didymus. By the end of the fourth century it is all but universally accepted, p. lx1ii.
